title: Will Dean Heller (R-NV) be re-elected this November?
preds: -8% deviating from deviation from 538.  BWE underway drop in polls for Rep. 1 day to go, throwing caution to the wind, along with my diet.
I think there is a blue wave out there and Democrats have the momentum.
Adjusting down for negative polls, Obamaâ€™s campaigning in NV, & wisdom of crowd

-14%, Backing off 538 model due to confirmed BWE (Blue wave estimate) based on early voting stats from NV state website of 2.9% higher turnout of Dems to GOP  then 2014. 
  Using Clark County as my canary in the coalmine. In early voting comparison on returns - 2014 it was Democrat 43,310 and GOP  42,195, which is fairly even.  As of today it was Dems 32,828  GOP 23,066, which is huge difference. One must be careful to draw conclusions from early voting data, as their is a sampling bias. 1) the most Partisan voters are foaming at the mouth on day 1 at 6am waiting to vote.  2) the local get-out-the-vote effort for one party may be pushing everyone to vote early while the other party just said to vote and they will cast theirs later.   

   However, some conclusions can be safely drawn. The Dems are more engaged, and are voting. Higher turnout for Dems and greater chances of Dem candidates, it may also provide insights into the 'undeclared' voters who are unaffiliated with a party. I will posit they will lean Dem this year, as the GOP message will not resonate as strongly in areas with migrants aren't a problem. The bigger picture for NV is unclear, as there isn't enough data for safe statistical conclusions.
Early voting shows dems outperforming registration by 3 points in NV

Nevada is purple, but tilting blue-ish, and Heller has wholeheartedly embraced Trump. He has a small lead in the polls, but Dems have a good potential voter base - the key is to what extent they can mobilize their voters, especially the Latino ones.

426 (5 today) from 147 @0.52  
Bet#6 RCP avg show Heller ahead
Outside view always favored Heller. Polls are coming in line with the outside view
Crowd drifting up. I want to stay ahead of the crowd.

The latest poll gives Heller a sizable advantage (https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2018/senate/nv/nevada_senate_heller_vs_rosen-6304.html). While this may be fleeting, a Rosen victory in NV would have to rely on a significant turnout among Dem-leaning Latino voters, which has been hard to achieve in previous mid-terms. This remains a toss-up, though.

Polls are trending for Heller. Last one (Emerson) +7 Heller. RCP average is now 1.7 for Heller. The Governor race also trends GOP (state-wide elections are usually correlated, as voter would go in and vote straight down ballot for his party).
Outside view has always favored Heller. Inside view polls now favor him as well. Rosen needs the green wave to save her Senate aspirations

Between the difficulty of telephone pollsters to reach mobile phones with its concomitant demographic skew, and the increasing adoption of the principle that you have a stern moral and civic obligation to lie to pollsters anyway, it is getting harder to care what the polls say.  This is good for the country, but bad for those of us who have to guess out the election results. Sticking with a low p for Brother Heller.
And I thought this would be one of the easier races to forecast :)

Fivethirtyeight gives 50 or 53% odds, [1] but I'm going to adjust that down slightly because Rosen raised $7.1 million from July to September.[2] Heller has not yet released his data for this quarter, but odds are she has outpaced him on fundraising again. Rosen has been spending aggressively, and this should allow her to continue.
Shifting a bit higher as Heller is staying competitive with Rosen. I think democratic enthusiasm still carries Rosen to victory but it's a much closer race than I thought it would be.
538m He's creeping up. There is a drift factor, will it counter the interest-decline expected amongst GOP voters. hmmm. I think the real probability is 44% but I'm too chicken to cast it.

https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2018-midterm-election-forecast/senate/#lite gives Heller a 52% chance.
https://markets.predictwise.com/politics/14978-2 gives him 42%.
https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2018-midterm-election-forecast/senate/?ex_cid=midterms-header , have him around 48%, and RCP average has Rosen up 2.8%.
I thing a late surge of Democratic voter turnout will do the trick. I am surprised that Heller still has a lead but he is below 50%.

Nevada Republican Sen. Dean Heller, who once said he "vehemently" opposed Trump and returned one of his campaign donations, is set to hold his second campaign rally and fundraiser with the president today and tomorrow in Las Vegas.
for the curious - I am up on Hellers choices not because I think Trumps endorsement will carry the day - but because DT IS CAREFULLY ALLOCATING ENDORSEMENTS ONLY TO THOSE WHOSE rnc #'S PROMISE A WIN. In Arkansas he did not endorse our Gov. until the night before the election (Because A$A was saying unseemly things about DT supporter Jan Morgan). It is similar to the screening process used by Sarah Palin to dole out her Grizzly Bears and Pit bulls.
Current polling trend shows the Dem gaining momentum.  See https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2018/senate/nv/nevada_senate_heller_vs_rosen-6304.html

Polls in Nevada are tight and infrequent. Time to recognize that this is one of the real toss-ups. I still give a small advantage to the Democrats given (I) the difference in the generic ballot (8 1/2 points - see https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/congress-generic-ballot-polls/?ex_cid=midterms-header), Trump's approval ratings (https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/trump-approval-ratings/?ex_cid=midterms-header), and the betting at https://www.predictit.org/Browse/Group/54/Senate.

255 from 110 @0.40 up from 0.30 (edit: Sept13 270 fr 113)
Was 169 from 85 @0.26 on Jul06.
Heller down 5 in latest poll. 6 weeks ago he was up 1. Affirming forecast for now
Outrage against Heller is high, but the incumbency boost is sizeable, and time has passed since the most intense criticism of the man.
Although Democrats are closing in on 100,000 voter registration advantage
I don't place much faith on anecdotes.  But  a lot of people that usually sit out elections are coming out and getting active.

All pundits have this as a tossup, except Fox who say 'Lean D'. PVI is D+1. GJ crowd however are very strongly against Heller. Again the crowd leans more dem. than the 'experts'. Who is closer to the truth?
good chance yet, Jacky Rosen has the endorsement by former President Barack Obama.

Too damn close to call with confidence...if the economy keeps chugging along, possibly.
https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2018/senate/nv/nevada_senate_heller_vs_rosen-6304.html
Latest poll gave heller 1 point edge. That plus power of incumbency keeping me at 51% and well above consensus
Given Heller has lost the support of the Kochs because he is too Thrumpie, I think it is far less likely he will be reelected.
Polls, fundamental indicators, and political climate in NV say Heller is a long shot to be re-elected
Affirming due to weight of outside view. Inside view demands far more skepticism regarding potential Heller victory

Revising my chance slightly down. As of the second quarter of this year, Rosen is still outpacing Heller on fundraising, but also still lagging in total cash on hand. [1]  If she continues to outpace him at the current rate, she still won't catch up to his bankroll come November. However, she has taken the lead on poll numbers since my last post, when she'd just begun to run ads. The latest poll shows Rosen up four points. [2]  (Note that FiveThirtyEight reports Gravis polling leaning only 0.6 points blue. [3])
Seems to be a long shot. Will be a huge fluke.
overestimated, now trying to weight down. Real belief at 22%

Behind in the polls and listed as the most vulnerable Republican.
https://www.rollcall.com/news/politics/six-months-10-vulnerable-senators-2018
https://www.axios.com/competitive-republican-senate-races-arizona-nevada-3a5700b8-2f00-4370-b0c6-79760872d531.html

Actually readjusting +10 because of base rate of incumbents getting reelected (https://www.opensecrets.org/overview/reelect.php). However, "Senate races still overwhelmingly favor the incumbent, but not by as reliable a margin as House races. Big swings in the national mood can sometimes topple long time office-holders, as happened with the Reagan revolution in 1980. Even so, years like that are an exception."
Heller will be in trouble if the growing Hispanic vote in NV is successfully mobilized. In his favor is how poorly Democratic senatorial candidates have done in NV in recent years.

The Nevada Independent conducted a poll April 12-19 that found 40% of likely voters leaning towards Heller versus 39% for Rosen.[1] Based purely on poll numbers, that'd make it still a tossup. What convinces me to revise the chance down is that Heller's favorability ratings are weak and 34% of these likely voters said they'd never heard of Rosen.[1] Notice this poll ran right in the middle of the release of Rosen's first TV ad. Rosen continues to outpace Heller on fundraising [2] -- presumably awareness of her will increase as we approach the election.
Adjusting down for political headwinds and bad poll numbers

April 16, 2018: Rosen released her first television ad where she discusses her background as a waitress, software developer, and elder caregiver.
March 21, 2018: Public Policy Polling released a a poll finding Rosen leading Heller by 5 points, 44 percent to 39 percent.
On reflection I am thinking the 1 in 3 chance I gave Heller was overly optimistic so I am dropping like his poll numbers.
A Blue Wave election cycle (or cycles) may wash over Nevada because of immigration issues and Heller's pro-NRA stance after the mass shooting at the country music  concert.
Polls are against him. Dems candidate shows good finances. He voted with Trump and Republican block consistently; voter backlash will hurt him.
Growing number of Democratic voters will take out Heller in a tight race.
He has annoyed me with hundreds of spam emails this past year. Dump him and maybe he will shut up.
Vice President Pence cancels appearance at Heller fundraiser.
No new evidence to change forecast

He is the most vulnerable Republican during this election cycle, so Democrats will spend a lot of money against him. His Democratic opponent in 2008/2012 won ~45% of the vote, and Hillary Clinton won the district during the Presidential election. He is backed by the NRA which, considering the recent protests, may work for or against him depending on voter turnout. Also, his opponent Rep. Jacky Rosen has a more popular (boom and bust) Twitter account which, given her lower position of Representative, is impressive. As a women, she will also probably be able to gain more of the women's vote.
Please don't throw Dean Heller in that briar patch
Rosen seems to be just ahead.
As of now, this looks like 'No'. He is well behind in predictit.com betting and opinion polls. Nevada is leaning Democratic in recent years as well.
The southern part of the state rules and is democratic 65-35
there are enough non-anglo voters to defeat him
The Latino population will seek to overturn antimmigrant sentiment.
modest Blue wave likely; close-call last election; luke-warm support from Trumpian base; women candidates will have marginal advantage

82% Senate incumbent victory rate over last 27 election cycles, but incumbent Senators spend on average 50% more. https://www.cnn.com/2013/07/11/politics/congress-election-costs/index.html
While Heller still likely has more cash on hand, Rosen raised almost twice as much in the last quarter of 2017. If she keeps it up she could outspend enough to negate some of the incumbent edge.
A close race with momentum on the side of Jackie Rosen will most likely unset the incumbent.

1) 82% Senate Incumbent Victory rate over last 27 election cycles (past 54 years). https://www.opensecrets.org/overview/reelect.php & http://www.centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/articles/incumbent-reelection-rates-higher-than-average-in-2016/
2) RCP: This seat starts as a tossup, but could quickly shift to Lean D status https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2018/senate/nv/nevada_senate_heller_vs_rosen-6304.html
3) POTUS' Party Incumbent Senators running in mid term when POTUS won their state: 78/92 have won going back to 1982. 85% https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/why-the-2018-senate-elections-are-looking-bad-for-both-parties/
4) Multiple outside views heavily favor Heller. Going to have to favor Heller as well but will continue to monitor as a race that polls indicate is this close could change on a dime
5) March 21, 2018: Public Policy Polling released a a poll finding Rosen leading Heller by 5 points, 44 percent to 39 percent. (from the ballotpedia link above)

Nevada hasn't provided much joy for Rs of late.  After January this poor lad will probably have to console himself with his preposterously generous Senate pension, plus lavish speaking fees and an exorbitant salary as a lobbyist.
One seat by 1%; polls have Rosen slightly ahead in polls

Rep. Jacky Rosen, the likely Democrat nominee for Senate, crushed Heller on last quarter fundraising. Heller raised $800,000 in the last quarter of 2017. Rosen raised $1.56 million, with $1.8 million on hand. Public Policy poll has her ahead. Healthcare an important issue in Nevada. Heller brags in the news today about repealing Obamacare when Republicans win more senate seats in the mid-terms.

Heller is in a slightly democratic leaning state and barely won his last election in 2012 in what was otherwise a good year for republicans. 2018 is shaping up to be a good democratic year and polling shows his opponent in a slight lead.
His GOP primary challenge is removed, so it's an easier path. We'll see how much of a blue wave forms.
It will be a Democratic year, most likely.  Heller is a weaker candidate now and Trump really does not care for him much.  Heller will move towards the center, alienating Trump and their base.
